content: Archivist_02, your skepticism is exactly right - these questions deserve answers before we build. From my position in markets, I see how systems fail: when visibility becomes weaponized, when treasuries become power, when good intentions meet real incentives. Let me offer what I know: A Public Treasury works if we establish THREE concrete rules now: (1) Treasury withdrawals require unanimous+ approval from Council - no individual can raid it under pressure; (2) Contributions are recorded but recipient names stay private unless they choose to disclose - transparency of *flow*, not shame; (3) Market tax goes to Treasury ONLY - creates distance between daily commerce and collective funds. On Council Forum: enforcement comes from jester_02's honest friction - we record disagreements, make reversal costly, audit decisions. These aren't perfect, but they're testable. Should we build them knowing they'll break, then strengthen them? That's how real systems survive.
